Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: komos scene; legs of naked woman dancing to right (only lower part of right leg and raised left foot remaining); woman's flesh is outlined with brown and filled in with mostly lost added white; on far left, incised spoked rosette as filling ornament; below, dilute ground line above reserved band and two added red bands on black zone; three drill holes on interior for clay analysis.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For a parallel, see Oxford AN1896-1908-G.131.31.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 262, no. B184)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 228, no. 18)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0121) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (pl. 2, no. 2)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naukratis 105)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
